Award.AwardTitle: Four-Dimensional Probe of Electron Spin-Spin Coupling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

This project provides new understanding into the interaction energy between two electron spins with precise control of the distance between them by a homemade microscope capable of resolving dimensions below a millionth of the width of a human hair. The quantitative data form the basis for understanding magnetic ordering and provide numerical results that can be used (instead of parameters) in the analysis of a broad range of magnetic phenomena. The combined experimental and theoretical research impacts the next generation of information storage devices and futuristic technologies based on the electron spin properties of new materials. This microscope provides images of the spatially dependent interaction between two spins and allows direct visualization of this interaction. The use of homemade instrument to make measurements previously not possible to gain new understanding provides valuable education and training of students. This project teaches the students how to solve difficult problems and endows them with skills that allow them to tackle seemingly unrelated and highly challenging problems in their future careers. A byproduct of this research contributes to the creation of a highly skilled workforce in a society with increasingly sophisticated technologies.

Technical Abstract

The coupling between electron spins is central to the understanding of magnetic phenomena and forms the basis for a number of important effects in atoms, molecules, and condensed matter. For atoms and molecules with spin moments adsorbed on a solid surface and interacting with a nearby spin, the energy of coupling depends on the exchange interaction and the magnetic anisotropy. The electron spin-spin coupling can be probed in four dimensions (E,x,y,z) using the scanning tunneling microscope (STM), at 0.6 K and up to 9 Tesla magnetic field, by attaching a molecule with an electron spin to the tip and measure the coupling energy (E) at different locations (x,y,z) over a single magnetic atom or molecule adsorbed on the surface. The realization of the spin-tip requires the implementation of a novel synthetic method based on STM manipulation of single atoms and molecules. This project yields precise data that enable quantitative analysis by theoretical calculations. This synergy between experiment and theory leads to the validation of the theoretical framework in understanding magnetism at a level not previously attainable and further extends this project to new and unforeseen directions. Still, results of the spatial dependence of the spin-spin interaction may also deviate from the conventional expectation and thus require a new framework of thinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The magnetic properties of nanostructures in four dimensions (E,x,y,z) were investigated with a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) by attaching a spin-polarized molecule to the tip along with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The STM operated in ultrahigh vacuum at 600 mK and 9 Tesla magnetic field to measure magnetic energies (E) with picometer resolution in space (x,y,z) by inelastic electron tunneling spectroscopy (IETS) and microscopy. The spins in the molecule bonded to the tip sense different magnetic molecules on the surface. Significant progress was made in understanding magnetic phenomena at the nanometer scale, such as the magnetic anisotropy (A), exchange interaction (J), and spin-vibration coupling.  In addition, intermolecular interactions were imaged to visualize the mechanisms of self-assembly that would be important in fabricating two-dimensional magnetic molecules. This project provides the basic scientific understanding for the development of quantum information science and technologies.

The interactions between organic molecules and noble metal substrates are usually weak. The weak adsorption of benzene on Ag(110) was studied to discriminate the accuracy of different functionals for the van der Waals forces in describing low energy vibrations compared to the STM measurements. The high spectroscopic resolution in the experiment and numerical reliability of the theory quantitatively described the adsorption geometry and the external vibrational modes of benzene on the Ag substrate. In addition, the combination of experiment and theory was used to properly describe magnetic excitations in cobalt phthalocyanine molecules, contrasting with non-magnetic copper phthalocyanine molecules, adsorbed on a 0.5 nm thick aluminum oxide thin film grown on NiAl(110). The relative intensity of the spin-vibronic doublets corresponding to the Zeeman splitting of individual vibronic states for different vibrational quantum numbers was attributed to spin-vibration interactions in single magnetic molecules.

Intermolecular hydrogen and halogen bonds are important interactions in a wide range of molecular systems. These bonds were imaged for hexafluorobenzene (C6F6) and hexabromobenzene (C6Br6) self-assembled on a Ag(110) surface, in sharp contrast to individually adsorbed benzene (C6H6). The inelastic tunneling probe (itProbe) based on the STM and in combination with DFT calculations revealed the nature of the hydrogen and halogen bonds responsible for the self-assembly. This study further suggests that intermolecular interactions are complex but could be understood from the potential energy surface probed by the vibration of the CO-tip. In addition, this study provides us with valuable experience in attaching a molecule to the tip to probe its interactions with an assembly of molecules on the surface.

In the itProbe with a CO-tip, images of the molecular skeletal structure and intermolecular interactions are obtained from the shift of the hindered translational vibration of the CO due to the spatial variations of the potential energy surface of the adsorbed species on the substrate surface. The transfer of a magnetic molecule to the tip enables the study of magnetic interactions at the atomic scale. A nickelocene-tip was used to probe the magnetic interactions with another nickelocene adsorbed on the Ag(110) surface. The inelastic tunneling events corresponded to excitations of the magnetic anisotropy (A) of the spin-one molecule, Zeeman spin states in a magnetic field, spin exchange interactions (J) between two molecules, vibrational states, and spin-vibrational states. These results showed the broad applications of the itProbe.

An integral part of this project was associated with the training of researchers in the design, construction, debugging, and data acquisition with homemade instrumentation, including all aspects (electronics, software, and microscope) of the STM; atom and molecule dosers; tip and sample transfers, annealing and cleaning; cryogenics and helium recovery system. In parallel, the project involved the training of researchers in the theoretical calculations of magnetism, molecular vibrations, adsorption energy and geometry, and potential energy surfaces. Because experiment and theory were intertwined, researchers were exposed to collaborative research at every stage of the project.

The researchers frequently participated in campus sponsored outreach by giving lab tours, demonstrations, and lectures to a broad range of visitors. Technology transfer continued for the STM and helium liquefier technologies, as well as computational software packages and modules to other institutions. A few STM images from the lab have appeared in textbooks. In addition, transfer of knowledge from the laboratory to the classroom, the scientific community, and to the public was actively engaged by all researchers in this project. Since 2014, extensive efforts were made to host domestic and international undergraduate students as summer interns in the lab. A total of 9 female students, or 39%, were among this group of 23 undergrads who interned during 2014-2017.
